questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of dull pain in the right buttock that worsens with defecation. He says that he cannot work at the office anymore because “sitting down hurts.” During this time, he has not had any changes in stool frequency or appearance. He has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 3-cm erythematous, tender, fluctuant mass in the right perianal region with no exudate. Digital rectal examination elicits pain. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy may be considered in patients with a perianal abscess after they have received the first-line treatment. This individual has not received any treatment yet, so antibiotic therapy would not be appropriate at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Sitz baths are indicated for the symptomatic treatment of hemorrhoids and anal fissures, both of which can manifest with buttock pain exacerbated upon defecation and local tenderness on digital rectal examination. However, in patients with hemorrhoids, examination typically shows a firm, rather than fluctuant, perianal mass; in patients with anal fissures, a perianal laceration is typically seen. Moreover, both hemorrhoids and anal fissures typically manifest with rectal bleeding and perianal pruritus, none of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Rubber band ligation is indicated for the treatment of symptomatic internal hemorrhoids, which can manifest with buttock pain exacerbated upon defecation and a tender perianal mass. Furthermore, internal hemorrhoids due to chronic constipation are common in patients with hypothyroidism. However, examination typically shows a firm, rather than fluctuant, perianal mass, and hemorrhoids also usually manifest with rectal bleeding and perianal pruritus.

D) CORRECT:

Incision and drainage is the first-line treatment of perianal abscesses. Most perianal abscesses result from obstruction of anal crypt glands (e.g., due to bacteria, fecal debris, or foreign matter) with subsequent infection and abscess formation. Prompt management is essential for the prevention of possible complications such as secondary fistula formation, tissue necrosis, and anal sphincter involvement with consequent fecal incontinence. While imaging (e.g., anal ultrasonography, CT, MRI) can confirm the diagnosis and show the extent of tissue involvement, treatment is generally initiated based on high clinical suspicion. Postoperative antibiotics are not routinely used but can be considered in certain patients (e.g., immunocompromised individuals).

Other causes of perianal abscesses include inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn disease), complicated diverticulitis, and malignancy (e.g., colorectal cancer).
Image Description:

There is a prominent area of erythema and swelling on the left buttock and perianal region.

This is the typical appearance of an anal abscess.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is the treatment of choice for symptomatic pilonidal cysts, which can manifest with buttock pain upon sitting and may develop in the perianal region. However, most pilonidal cysts develop at the top of the intergluteal fold, in the sacrococcygeal region. Furthermore, pilonidal cysts most commonly have a sinus tract opening with draining purulent discharge.
questions.hint: Buttock pain exacerbated upon defecation along with an erythematous, tender, fluctuant mass in the perianal region is consistent with a perianal abscess.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 35-year-old man presents to urgent care reporting 2 days of acute-onset perianal pain and malaise. The pain started gradually but has intensified during the past 12 hours; it is persistent and does not worsen with bowel movements. The patient also reports feeling a lump near his anus and, in the past few hours, has noted a small amount of purulent drainage.
On presentation, he has a temperature of 38.1°C, a heart rate of 82 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 124/74 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals an erythematous, palpable mass immediately lateral to the anus.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pilonidal abscesses occur in the gluteal cleft superior to the anus near the coccyx, rather than in the perianal area.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical presentation — acute perianal pain; an erythematous, palpable mass with drainage; and a fever — is consistent with a perianal abscess. The pain of a perianal abscess is often persistent, and it may or may not worsen with bowel movements. The diagnosis can often be made on physical examination alone, which also helps to rule out other potential causes of anal pain. A rectal examination, imaging with CT or MRI, or both may be necessary for deep abscesses. Appropriate treatment for a perianal abscess includes incision, drainage, and antibiotics.

Key learning point: Perianal abscesses typically manifest with acute perianal pain and an erythematous mass, with drainage near the anus.

C) INCORRECT:

Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic inflammatory condition of the follicles in intertriginous areas such as the axillae, groin, perianal area, inframammary region, and genitals. Characteristic skin changes include comedones, sinus tracts, scarring, and inflammatory nodules, none of which are described in this patient. A single inflamed mass would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombosed hemorrhoids manifest with rectal or perianal pain that is often persistent and may worsen with bowel movements. Physical examination often reveals a purple-colored, hard lump (external hemorrhoid) at the anal verge. Purulent drainage would not occur, and systemic symptoms such as fever are not common.

E) INCORRECT:

Anal fissures can cause acute anal pain, but the pain would worsen with bowel movements. Fissures may be visible on physical examination as a small tear in the anoderm distal to the dentate line.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with three months of intermittent purulent discharge from a small opening near his anus. He reports that a painful swelling in the anal area spontaneously ruptured a few weeks ago, followed by recurrent discharge. He denies rectal bleeding or constipation. On examination, there is a tiny opening lateral to the anal verge with a small amount of seropurulent fluid.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

External hemorrhoids are dilated venous plexuses near the anal margin, presenting as soft swellings that can become painful when thrombosed. The described lateral opening with recurrent seropurulent drainage suggests a chronic infectious process, not a vascular anomaly. The absence of rectal bleeding and engorged venous tissue further differentiates this from external hemorrhoids.

B) CORRECT:

A perianal fistula manifests as an abnormal tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. The patient's history of a painful perianal swelling that spontaneously ruptured suggests an abscess, likely from infection in the anal glands, evolved into a fistula. The intermittent purulent discharge is characteristic of a chronic fistulous tract, as residual infection drains through the opening. This condition often follows cryptoglandular infections where incomplete drainage of an abscess leads to fistula formation. Recognizing the evolution of symptoms and physical findings is crucial for diagnosis.

Key learning point: A perianal fistula often results from a ruptured perianal abscess and presents with a history of swelling, rupture, and persistent discharge.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anal orifice of a patient: The external orifice of the anal fistula is seen at 6 O'clock.
A malleable metallic probe has been inserted through the external orifice to the internal orifice (within the anal canal) to identify the course of the fistulous tract.

C) INCORRECT:

A pilonidal cyst typically presents with a discharging sinus in the sacrococcygeal region, often due to hair entrapment and infection. It usually occurs in the midline near the natal cleft, not lateral to the anal verge. The patient's history of a painful anal swelling that ruptured is not characteristic of a pilonidal cyst.

D) INCORRECT:

Anal fissures are linear tears in the anoderm, presenting with severe pain during defecation and bright red bleeding. The absence of rectal bleeding and painful bowel movements, along with chronic purulent drainage from a lateral opening, makes an anal fissure unlikely. Anal fissures typically occur in the posterior midline.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of recurrent painful swelling near the anus that drains pus intermittently. He works a sedentary job and notices discomfort after prolonged sitting. Examination shows a small external opening close to the anal verge, and gentle probing suggests a short, superficial tract. Anoscopy reveals no high internal opening, and the external sphincter does not appear involved.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the pelvis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms and examination findings indicate a low, simple perianal fistula with a short, superficial tract and no involvement of the external sphincter. Surgical fistulotomy is the preferred treatment for such cases, as it involves unroofing the fistula tract to allow drainage and healing while preserving sphincter function. This procedure minimizes the risk of postoperative incontinence and has high success rates in resolving symptoms and preventing recurrence.

Key learning point: Fistulotomy is the preferred treatment for low-lying perianal fistulas, as it involves opening the fistula tract to promote healing and has a high success rate.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is used to evaluate complex fistulas with deep extensions or multiple tracts. The patient's fistula is simple, with a clearly defined tract and no sphincter involvement, making MRI unnecessary for management.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic antibiotics are indicated for acute infections with systemic symptoms, such as fever or cellulitis. This patient has a chronic fistula with no signs of systemic infection. The underlying issue is an epithelialized fistula tract, which requires surgical intervention rather than antibiotics.

D) INCORRECT:

A cutting seton is typically used for complex fistulas involving a significant portion of the anal sphincter, such as high transsphincteric fistulas, to prevent incontinence. The described fistula is simple and superficial, with no sphincter involvement, making a cutting seton unnecessarily invasive.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of severe throbbing anal pain, fever, and chills. He has a 10-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Examination reveals a fluctuant, erythematous swelling measuring approximately 3 cm in the perianal region, with significant tenderness on palpation. The patient reports difficulty sitting. No drainage or necrotic skin changes are noted (see lab result).

Temperature
38.7°C



Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
14.0 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombosed external hemorrhoids present as painful, firm, bluish nodules at the anal verge, lacking systemic signs like fever and chills. The lesion is nonfluctuant, consisting of clotted blood, unlike the fluctuant, pus-filled swelling seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Anal fissures cause severe anal pain, especially during defecation, but do not present with fluctuant masses or systemic infection signs. The presence of a fluctuant, erythematous swelling and systemic symptoms like fever and leukocytosis suggests an infectious process, not an anal fissure.

C) CORRECT:

A perianal abscess is a localized collection of pus due to infection in the anal glands, often seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. It manifests with severe, throbbing anal pain, fever, and chills. Examination typically reveals a fluctuant, tender, erythematous swelling in the perianal region. The elevated white blood cell count supports an infectious process. Prompt surgical intervention, such as incision and drainage, is necessary to prevent complications.

Key learning point: A painful perianal swelling with fever and leukocytosis in a diabetic patient is most indicative of a perianal abscess.

D) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing fasciitis involves rapidly spreading infection with severe pain, crepitus, and necrotic skin changes. This patient has a well-circumscribed fluctuant swelling without skin necrosis or crepitus, indicating a localized abscess rather than widespread tissue destruction.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with diabetes mellitus presents with a 2-day history of worsening perianal pain and fever. He reports difficulty sitting and defecating. Physical examination shows a fluctuant, tender subcutaneous mass lateral to the anal verge with surrounding erythema extending 4 cm. Vital signs are BP, 130/80; P, 88; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F). Which factor most strongly indicates the need for a surgical consultation for operative drainage under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The lateral location describes an ischiorectal abscess, but location alone does not determine drainage approach. Superficial ischiorectal abscesses can sometimes be drained at bedside if there are no other concerning features.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Fever with extensive cellulitis (4 cm of surrounding erythema) suggests systemic infection and significant local tissue involvement, which indicates the need for operative drainage under general anesthesia.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluctuance indicates a mature abscess for which drainage is appropriate, but it does not by itself determine the drainage approach. Simple perianal abscesses with fluctuance can often be drained at the bedside with local anesthesia.

D) INCORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus is a comorbid risk factor that increases the risk of infection and healing complications, but it alone does not determine the drainage approach.

E) INCORRECT:

A two-day duration is typical for the presentation of an abscess and does not influence the choice of drainage approach.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with diabetes presents with 4 days of worsening anorectal pain and fever. He reports difficulty sitting and avoidance of defecation due to pain. Vital signs are BP, 140/85; P, 98; T, 38.9°C (102.0°F). Perianal inspection shows no visible swelling or erythema. Digital rectal examination shows a tender, fluctuant mass in the rectum with purulent drainage. Laboratory results show leukocytosis with left shift. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bedside incision and drainage is appropriate for superficial perianal and ischiorectal abscesses. An intersphincteric abscess requires operative drainage under general anesthesia.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI pelvis is indicated for occult abscesses, recurrent or complex fistulas, or diagnostic uncertainty. Imaging is not indicated in this patient and would cause unnecessary delay in definitive treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics alone are insufficient for abscess treatment, which requires drainage. The presence of systemic symptoms, diabetes, and leukocytosis further contraindicate outpatient management and necessitate urgent surgical intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

CT scan may be used in acute settings for diagnostic uncertainty, but this patient has clear clinical findings of an abscess. Imaging would delay definitive treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation suggests an intersphincteric abscess based on the tender rectal mass on digital examination without external perianal findings. The presence of diabetes, systemic symptoms, and leukocytosis indicates that this patient requires urgent surgical consultation for operative drainage under general anesthesia rather than bedside drainage.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with diabetes presents with a 4-day history of progressive perianal discomfort and low-grade fever. He has no history of inflammatory bowel disease. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F). Perianal inspection shows mild erythema without obvious swelling or fluctuance. On digital rectal examination, there is a tender, indurated area in the posterior rectal wall. Complete blood count shows leukocytosis with a left shift. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Anoscopy and probing of the perianal area
Incision and drainage in the emergency department
MRI pelvis with and without IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics alone do not adequately treat anorectal abscesses, which typically require procedural intervention. Based on the patient’s clinical signs, outpatient management is not appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Probing during anoscopy should be avoided outside the operating room, as it can cause trauma or spread infection. Additionally, anoscopy alone does not reliably detect deep anorectal abscesses.

C) INCORRECT:

While CT can identify abscesses, it is not the preferred imaging modality for evaluating anorectal abscesses. Other modalities have higher sensitivity and better resolution for demonstrating abscesses and associated anatomy, especially when the diagnosis is not clear from clinical findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage is inappropriate without first confirming the presence and location of an abscess. This patient's physical examination findings suggest a deeper abscess for which simple drainage in the emergency department may not be suitable.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- MRI of the pelvis with and without IV contrast is the preferred imaging modality for suspected occult abscesses, particularly when physical examination findings are subtle. This patient's presentation suggests an intersphincteric abscess, and MRI provides superior resolution for demonstrating abscesses and associated fistula tracts.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of perianal drainage. Six weeks ago, he underwent incision and drainage of a perianal abscess. On examination, there is a small opening in the perianal skin with purulent drainage. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT scan of the pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics alone are typically insufficient for managing chronic perianal drainage. Further evaluation and intervention are usually necessary to address the underlying cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeat incision and drainage is generally reserved for acute abscesses. Persistent drainage without signs of abscess may indicate a different pathology requiring alternative management.

C) INCORRECT:

Imaging can assist in complex or atypical cases, but straightforward clinical cases generally do not require immediate imaging to guide management.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation is consistent with anal fistula formation, a common complication following perianal abscess drainage. The ductal connection between the anorectal lumen and perianal skin requires surgical repair. Multiple surgical options exist, including fistulotomy, seton placement, and other techniques that require specialist evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Delaying treatment is inappropriate for anal fistulas. These require surgical intervention and will not resolve spontaneously. Symptoms will persist or worsen if definitive evaluation or treatment is delayed.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of 4 days of severe, throbbing pain near his anus. The pain is exacerbated by sitting and defecation. He reports feeling feverish for the past 24 hours. He has no significant medical history. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. A photograph of the perianal region is shown. Palpation reveals an exquisitely tender and fluctuant mass. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe a 10-day course of oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
Recommend warm sitz baths and outpatient surgical follow-up
Perform a needle aspiration for culture and sensitivity
Obtain a CT scan of the pelvis with contrast
Incision and drainage of the affected area

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While this patient has signs of a bacterial infection, antibiotics are insufficient as a standalone treatment for a perianal abscess. Antibiotics have poor penetration into the encapsulated abscess cavity and cannot resolve the infection without controlling the source. Antibiotics are typically reserved as an adjunctive therapy for patients with significant cellulitis, systemic signs of infection, or immunosuppression.

B) INCORRECT:

Warm sitz baths can offer symptomatic relief for anorectal complaints but are not a definitive treatment for a perianal abscess. Given the patient’s severe pain and systemic signs of infection like fever and tachycardia, delaying drainage is inappropriate. Such a delay would risk abscess expansion, spontaneous and inadequate rupture, fistula formation, or progression to sepsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Needle aspiration is an inadequate method for draining a perianal abscess. The purulent material is often thick and loculated, and aspiration alone typically fails to completely evacuate the cavity, leading to a high rate of treatment failure and recurrence. While a culture may be obtained during drainage, a formal wide incision is necessary for definitive treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan may be used to evaluate for deep-space anorectal abscesses. However, this patient has a superficial abscess that is palpable on physical exam as a fluctuant mass. Therefore, the diagnosis is clinical, and imaging is not required. Obtaining a CT scan would unnecessarily delay definitive treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Prompt incision and drainage is the definitive treatment for any abscess as it provides immediate source control by evacuating the purulent material, which relieves the patient's pain and prevents the infection from spreading to deeper tissues or causing systemic complications such as sepsis. Although antibiotics may be used as an adjunct, particularly in cases with systemic signs such as fever, they are not a substitute for surgical drainage. Up to 50% of patients with a perianal abscess will develop a chronic fistula-in-ano.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of acute, localized, throbbing perianal pain, fever, and a tender, erythematous, and fluctuant mass is consistent with a perianal abscess.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with four days of severe, throbbing pain in his anal region. The pain is constant and exacerbated by sitting or having a bowel movement. He has also felt feverish. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 3-cm, tender, erythematous, and fluctuant mass at the 7 o'clock position of the perianal skin. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe a 10-day course of oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
Administer intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
Obtain a CT scan of the pelvis with contrast
Incision and drainage of the collection
Recommend sitz baths and oral analgesics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treating a formed abscess with oral antibiotics alone is inadequate. While trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole may cover common causative organisms, this nanagement approach would lead to treatment failure and potential worsening of the infection.

B) INCORRECT:

While this patient is febrile and has an infection, antibiotics alone are insufficient for treating a formed abscess. Antibiotic penetration into the abscess cavity is poor, and without definitive treatment, the infection will not resolve. Antibiotics are considered an adjunctive therapy to be given after the definitive procedure, not as the primary initial step.

C) INCORRECT:

Imaging such as a CT scan is not necessary for a simple, superficial perianal abscess that is clearly identified on physical examination. The diagnosis is clinical, based on the tender, erythematous, and fluctuant mass. Imaging is reserved for cases in which there is suspicion of a deeper, more complex abscess (e.g., ischioanal or supralevator), recurrent abscesses, or if the physical examination is equivocal.

D) CORRECT:

The cardinal principle of abscess management is source control, which is achieved through incision and drainage (I&D). The physical examination finding of a fluctuant mass indicates a mature, drainable collection. I&D provides immediate symptom relief and is the definitive treatment. Delaying drainage can lead to complications such as fistula-in-ano or extension into deeper spaces. Antibiotics are often used as an adjunct after drainage, especially in patients signs of systemic infection (e.g., fever), but they are not a substitute for surgical drainage.

E) INCORRECT:

Sitz baths and analgesics are supportive care measures that can provide symptomatic relief for various anorectal conditions. However, they are not a definitive treatment for a perianal abscess. Relying on conservative management alone would allow the infection to progress, potentially leading to more severe complications. These measures are often recommended after the initial management step.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of a tender, erythematous, and fluctuant perianal mass is classic for a perianal abscess.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents with three days of severe pain around the anus that worsens with sitting. He reports low-grade fevers and occasional purulent discharge. Physical examination reveals marked tenderness in the perianal region. Digital rectal examination shows a firm, fluctuant area between the internal and external anal sphincters. There is no visible external swelling.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ischiorectal abscesses typically present with a palpable lateral swelling in the ischiorectal fossa, which is a fat-filled space outside the anal sphincter complex. The absence of visible external swelling and the specific location of the fluctuant area between the sphincters argue against an ischiorectal abscess.

B) INCORRECT:

Pilonidal cysts are located in the midline of the natal cleft, just superior to the anus, and often present with a visible sinus or external swelling. The firm, fluctuant area between the anal sphincters, without external swelling, distinguishes this condition from a pilonidal cyst.

C) INCORRECT:

Anal fissures are linear tears in the anoderm, usually on the posterior midline, causing severe pain during defecation and bright red blood. They do not present with a fluctuant mass or purulent discharge, which are indicative of an abscess.

D) CORRECT:

Intersphincteric abscesses manifest with severe perianal pain, especially when sitting, and may present with low-grade fevers and purulent discharge. These abscesses form between the internal and external anal sphincters, often due to infection of anal glands. On digital rectal examination, a firm, fluctuant mass is palpable in the intersphincteric space, indicating pus collection. The absence of visible external swelling further supports this diagnosis. Understanding the anatomy of the anal canal and the typical progression of infections in this region is crucial for accurate diagnosis.

Key learning point: Intersphincteric abscess presents with severe perianal pain, fever, and purulent discharge, and is characterized by tenderness and bogginess on digital rectal examination.
